segments.speaker: clinician
segments.text: Good afternoon, Sarah. It's good to see you again. How have you been doing since our last session two weeks ago?

segments.speaker: patient
segments.text: Hi. Honestly, it's been a really tough couple of weeks. The insomnia has gotten worse. I'm maybe getting three or four hours a night now, and I feel exhausted all the time.

segments.speaker: clinician
segments.text: I'm sorry to hear that. Three to four hours is significantly less than what you were getting before. When did you notice this change?

segments.speaker: patient
segments.text: It started about a week after our last session. My mom came to stay with us, and things have been really tense. She keeps making comments about my parenting, and I just lie awake at night replaying those conversations.

segments.speaker: clinician
segments.text: That sounds like a significant stressor. How is your relationship with your mother typically?

segments.speaker: patient
segments.text: Complicated. We've always had a difficult dynamic. She's very critical, especially about how I'm raising Emma. Last week she told me I'm too permissive and that's why Emma has tantrums. I know she's probably wrong, but it still hurts. I ended up crying in the bathroom after she left the room.

segments.speaker: clinician
segments.text: It sounds like her criticism really affects you deeply, even when you intellectually know it may not be accurate. How has this been impacting your mood overall?

segments.speaker: patient
segments.text: My mood has definitely been lower. I've been feeling more irritable with my husband and with Emma, which I hate. I snapped at Emma yesterday for something small and then felt terrible about it. I've also noticed I don't really enjoy things the way I used to. Even reading, which I love, feels like a chore.

segments.speaker: clinician
segments.text: You're describing anhedonia - that loss of pleasure in activities you normally enjoy. Combined with the sleep issues and irritability, I want to check in on something. Have you had any thoughts of hurting yourself or not wanting to be here?

segments.speaker: patient
segments.text: No, nothing like that. I mean, sometimes I wish I could just escape for a while, like go on vacation alone. But I don't have thoughts about hurting myself. I have Emma to think about. She needs me.

segments.speaker: clinician
segments.text: I'm glad to hear that, and it's clear Emma is a strong protective factor for you. Are you still taking the sertraline as prescribed?

segments.speaker: patient
segments.text: Yes, 50mg every morning. I haven't missed any doses. Although I've been wondering if maybe we should increase it? A friend of mine is on 100mg and she says it helped her a lot more at that dose.

segments.speaker: clinician
segments.text: It's good that you're consistent with the medication. Regarding the dose, that's something to discuss with Dr. Martinez. I can include a note about your symptoms in my summary for her. How is the medication sitting with you otherwise? Any side effects?

segments.speaker: patient
segments.text: The nausea went away after the first few weeks. Sometimes I feel a bit jittery in the mornings, but it passes. Nothing too bad. I just wish it was helping more with the sleep.

segments.speaker: clinician
segments.text: The jitteriness can be a common side effect. Let's talk about sleep hygiene for a moment. What does your typical evening routine look like now, especially since your mother arrived?

segments.speaker: patient
segments.text: It's been all over the place honestly. We usually have dinner around 7, then I help Emma with homework and get her to bed by 8:30. After that, my mom and I often end up talking, which sometimes turns into arguments. By the time I go to bed, it's usually 11 or later, and my mind is racing. I've been scrolling on my phone in bed a lot too, probably until midnight most nights.

segments.speaker: clinician
segments.text: I'm hearing a few things there - late-night difficult conversations, phone use in bed, and going to bed with an activated mind. These are all things that can significantly impact sleep quality.

segments.speaker: patient
segments.text: Yeah, I know the phone thing is bad. I just can't seem to stop. It's like my brain needs the distraction. If I just lie there in the dark, all I can think about is everything I'm doing wrong.

segments.speaker: clinician
segments.text: That rumination pattern is really common, especially when we're stressed. Let's work on a strategy for that. Have you tried the breathing exercises we discussed last time? The 4-7-8 technique?

segments.speaker: patient
segments.text: I tried it a few times but I kept losing count or getting frustrated. It felt like another thing I was failing at. Maybe I wasn't doing it right.

segments.speaker: clinician
segments.text: There's no wrong way to do it - the goal is just to slow your nervous system down. Let's practice it together right now, and I'll guide you through it. We can also talk about setting some boundaries with your mother around evening conversations. How does that sound?

segments.speaker: patient
segments.text: Okay, that sounds good. I know I need to set boundaries with her. It's just so hard. Every time I try, she makes me feel guilty, like I'm being a bad daughter.

segments.speaker: clinician
segments.text: Setting boundaries with family members who trigger guilt is one of the hardest things to do. It's a skill that takes practice. For this week, I'd like you to try one small boundary - maybe ending conversations by 9 PM. We can role-play how to phrase that before you leave today.

segments.speaker: patient
segments.text: That would be helpful. I never know what to say that doesn't sound rude. And maybe if I can get to bed earlier with less on my mind, the sleep will improve.

segments.speaker: clinician
segments.text: Exactly. Let's also set up a simple wind-down routine - no phone after 10 PM, the breathing exercise, and maybe some light reading instead of screen time. We'll check in on how all of this is going in our next session. Your homework this week is the 9 PM conversation boundary and the phone-free wind-down routine. How are you feeling about that?

segments.speaker: patient
segments.text: Nervous but hopeful, I guess. It feels manageable when you put it that way. Two specific things I can try.

segments.speaker: clinician
segments.text: That's exactly right - small, specific steps. And remember, it's okay if it's not perfect. We're looking for progress, not perfection. Let's do that breathing exercise now, and then we'll role-play the boundary conversation.
